body: When I set batch_size below 1024,everything is OK,but when the batch_size is bigger than 1024,this error happens. and this bugs can be reproduce in mnist example.

@piiswrong No problem

I'll move opr_name at last and add some comments tonight

My bad, I should init the NDArrayIter with batchSize then everything works great!

``` scala
//change 
val valData: NDArrayIter = new NDArrayIter(data, label)
//to
val valData: NDArrayIter = new NDArrayIter(data, label, 32)
```

hi, i trained 103G .rec file, and the RAM using is less than 20G.
if using one GPU for your big dataset which it takes > 3 hrs is normal.
http://arxiv.org/abs/1505.00393
do you update the submodule?
Actually, I see now that this is to resolve ambiguities. Closing the issue.
Sounds like a cudnn issue. cudnn probably doesn't support batchsize > 1024. I suggest you ask on nvidia forum
@antinucleon Any progress on this issue?
@zihaolucky Seems that you built python and scala api with different `libmxnet.so`
The documentation for python lives under http://mxnet.io/packages/python/index.html
How is the mean image being computed? Is it computed first time the model is run on the training set, then stored, then subtracted from the images on the test set?

great job! 

I heard that tensorflow has tools to visualize on which gpu each operator is evaluated, and also show the communication between gpus. such information is often useful when users want to check everything is fine.
Can you show the scripts you are using?

On my machine

```
> mx.set.seed(0)
> devices = lapply(1:2, function(i) {
+ mx.cpu(i)
+ })
> # create the model
> model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(softmax, X=dtrain, eval.data=dtest,
+ ctx=devices, num.round=1,
+ learning.rate=0.1, momentum=0.9,
+ initializer=mx.init.uniform(0.07),
+ epoch.end.callback=mx.callback.save.checkpoint("chkpt"),
+ batch.end.callback=mx.callback.log.train.metric(100))
Auto-select kvstore type = local_update_cpu
Start training with 2 devices
Model checkpoint saved to chkpt-0001.params
> pred <- predict(model, dtest)
> label <- mx.io.extract(dtest, "label")
> dataX <- mx.io.extract(dtest, "data")
> # Predict with R's array
> pred2 <- predict(model, X=dataX)
Warning message:
In mx.model.select.layout.predict(X, model) :
  Auto detect layout input matrix, use colmajor..

> accuracy <- function(label, pred) {
+ ypred = max.col(t(as.array(pred)))
+ return(sum((as.array(label) + 1) == ypred) / length(label))
+ }
> print(paste0("Finish prediction... accuracy=", accuracy(label, pred)))
[1] "Finish prediction... accuracy=0.9627"
> print(paste0("Finish prediction... accuracy2=", accuracy(label, pred2)))
[1] "Finish prediction... accuracy2=0.9627"
> mx.set.seed(0)
> devices = lapply(1:2, function(i) {
+ mx.cpu(i)
+ })
> # create the model
> model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(softmax, X=dtrain, eval.data=dtest,
+ ctx=devices, num.round=1,
+ learning.rate=0.1, momentum=0.9,
+ initializer=mx.init.uniform(0.07),
+ epoch.end.callback=mx.callback.save.checkpoint("chkpt"),
+ batch.end.callback=mx.callback.log.train.metric(100))
Auto-select kvstore type = local_update_cpu
Start training with 2 devices
Model checkpoint saved to chkpt-0001.params
> # do prediction
> pred <- predict(model, dtest)
> label <- mx.io.extract(dtest, "label")
> dataX <- mx.io.extract(dtest, "data")
> # Predict with R's array
> pred2 <- predict(model, X=dataX)
Warning message:
In mx.model.select.layout.predict(X, model) :
  Auto detect layout input matrix, use colmajor..

> accuracy <- function(label, pred) {
+ ypred = max.col(t(as.array(pred)))
+ return(sum((as.array(label) + 1) == ypred) / length(label))
+ }
> print(paste0("Finish prediction... accuracy=", accuracy(label, pred)))
[1] "Finish prediction... accuracy=0.9627"
> print(paste0("Finish prediction... accuracy2=", accuracy(label, pred2)))
[1] "Finish prediction... accuracy2=0.9627"
```

This even happens with the script basic_model.R here at https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/R-package/demo
When I run it twice, i get different results: First time: 
"Finish prediction... accuracy=0.9587"
Second time: 
"Finish prediction... accuracy=0.9431"
Accuracy and accuracy 2 are the same on my machine too. However, when I run the script twice, I get different results.
I got `0.9627` in first and second time.

mshadow/src/extensions
I have tested the unittest cases and image classification CIFAR case.
@tornadomeet thank you !!!
You are right, thanks a lot!
It costs little on creating a new executor, the blank seemed to caused by the hot start of the new exectutor's first execution. Is there any way to avoid this? @tqchen
@feiyulv Is it possible to share the executors?

@sxjscience  I use the executor_mangager api, different executors can share the same memory, but the operators and other resources are reconstructed. The phenomenon is very strange. Since the fully cnn  also create a new executor every iteration, but it doesn't hurt the speed as I observed. For test, I use the same length in lstm for each batch, just  create a new executor sharing memory with the previous, the speed still drops.

What were the reasons to move aux into input? Any reason beside allowing aux to be named by variable? Would it be better to handle it as a special case?

Looks like it's impossible to unify aux and input in the front end now due to legacy issues. Unifying it in the backend seems to only add confusions and complicated wrappers.

Moving aux to input simplifies the case for NNVM and make it general to handle most cases. It also allows  aux to be named by variable in a natural way. 

Handling aux in the front end  means differentiating mutable inputs without immutable ones.  While that is not a must thing to do, doing so also makes things clear in some case, and consistent with the original NNVM terminology.

As "aux = muttable input", the terminology part is clear and most ops don't need to have aux in the first place. Future ops don't need to rely on the translation, and interface is simplified(most ops don't need to mutate inputs)

We can discuss the terminology in frontend later but since one can be consistent with another, I feel it is fine.
@anxingle @sxjscience I'm having the same issue compiling mxnet using cuda-8.0. I can compile it in cpu mode. I'm running make in the mxnet root directory, and I've set cuda related path in config.mk
I figured that when I chance USE_CUDA_PATH, there was an extra space. Everything works now.
https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm it is now opensourced here
See http://mxnet.io/packages/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput
Increasing the batch size?
Not sure why Travis CI fails to import graphviz. But this PR looks good to me to be merged.
@antinucleon Could this be fixed now that nnvm is in place.
Maybe because RNNs with long sequences are much larger graphs than a typical CNN. Graph construction speed should be improved once [nnvm](https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm) is in place.
This looks correct. Is your test set bigger than training set?
Not sure why this happens. But if you could provide some more details like that optimizers, learning rate, etc. are you using, maybe somebody could try to have some guessing of potential reasons.
Currently only cuDNN wrapped version is added. We plan to refine the interface and add examples using RNN symbol recently.
is there any error message? i didn't test window version before.

@pluskid The length does influence the speed, however construction is insiginifciant. I construct new  executor each batch, but use the default executor to do forward/backward, the gpu utilization won't drop.(For test, the sentence length is the same). It seems the hot start of the new executor causes the drop of speed
We should also consider supporting torch style axpby functions like a:add(0.5, b). These functions can save one to many ndarray alloc/free compared to a += 0.5*b

@piiswrong I agree. We can also add something like addmm and addbmm(https://github.com/torch/torch7/blob/master/doc/maths.md#res-torchaddmmres-v1-m-v2-mat1-mat2). Moreover, we can directly include some BLAS operations like GEMM.
@feiyulv Could you get an example that uses dummy data to help us reproduce the behavior?
after discussion with @piiswrong We will merge this in as it already passed most tests.

We will push followup updates to the nnvm branch.

@javelinjs We find that the scala test did not pass due to the fact that the newly added libnnvm.a is not linked, can you update the assembly script to add that?

@Trangle HI .I have tried your code of inception-v4 network and it works fine with 64 \*  64 images.
But why  it cost so much memory?
I use a geforce gtx 1070 display card and which has 8G memory in it. When i feed  299 \* 299 images into my model , mxnet crashed because of Out Of Memory. Then I resized the images to a small size which was (150,150),it also crashed because OOM .

Then I tried inception-v3 with 299 \* 299 images ,it worked fine.

What 's your memory consume when training with inception-v4 ? Thank you

`sym_gen` is a function that generates the symbol based on some arguments. `sym_gen(buckets[0])` is thus a symbol generated by feeding `buckets[0]` to `sym_gen`.
For RNN, if the lengths of the training sequences are different, you need to generate different symbols for each different length. That's the reason for using `sym_gen`. Refer to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/docs/how_to/bucketing.md

@sxjscience  You can reproduce this result with the rnn  example.
1. modify ltm_bucketing.py:
 set buckets=[100], batch_size=8
 run lstm_bucketing.py,  gpu utilization is about 80%
2. modify python/mxnet/executor_manager.py

```
    def load_data_batch(self, data_batch):
        """ load data and labels into arrays """
        if self.sym_gen is not None:
            key = data_batch.bucket_key
            if key not in self.execgrp_bucket:
                # create new bucket entry
                symbol = self.sym_gen(key)
                execgrp = DataParallelExecutorGroup(symbol, self.arg_names,
                                                    self.param_names, self.ctx,
                                                    self.slices, data_batch,
                                                    shared_group=self.execgrp)
                self.execgrp_bucket[key] = execgrp

            self.curr_execgrp = self.execgrp_bucket[key]
        else:
           # added for test 
            self.execgrp = DataParallelExecutorGroup(self.symbol, self.arg_names,
                                                    self.param_names, self.ctx,
                                                    self.slices, data_batch,
                                                    shared_group=self.execgrp)
            self.curr_execgrp = self.execgrp
```

run lstm_bucketing.py again, gpu utilization and speed will drop

@pluskid: one simple solution (which we use) is to have a high-level function create a view of all the sub-weights and biases (a dictionary of sub-dictionaries, one per layer), and then use this for initialization. If we decide on keeping the single parameter design, I can contribute a Python version of this.

Then for the Python initalizer: it already has special initialization logic for things like BatchNorm, you can have one for the RNN, which calls the extractor function and decides one the init method (like IRNN https://arxiv.org/pdf/1504.00941.pdf etc).
@sxjscience thx very much
@pluskid    Are this two all the same?
@albertyou2 inception-v4 takes 4000w+ parameters totally，and was designed for shape 299, in my machine with 980ti， i could only set batch-size at most 24 for running it.
@pluskid this problem was solved in #3161，and the function for layer and total parameter statistic was also added.

@tornadomeet thank you for your help, I sloved it.

@pluskid: I've already written a version for Mathematica. Its pretty simple: cuDNN has an API function for splitting this: `cudnnGetRNNLinLayerBiasParams` + `cudnnGetRNNLinLayerMatrixParams`. Using this + the docs for this makes it possible to work out whats going on (eg the biases are all at the end of the parameter vector). I then simply write a test making use of the definitions for GRU, LSTM, etc cuDNN uses, and check that my interpretation of the parameters are correct (and ensure that the splitter remains correct for future cuDNN versions).

I guess this bug occurs when it meet the operator that has multi outputs like `SliceChannel`, and change the code slightly to let the visualize process run normally:

```
key = input_name + "_output"
if "param" in input_node:
    params = input_node["param"]
    if "num_outputs" in params:
        key += str(int(params["num_outputs"]) - 1)
        params["num_outputs"] = int(params["num_outputs"]) - 1
shape = shape_dict[key][1:]

```

Now it works after unify the name convention
